Highly efficient synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates from alcohols and diethyl carbonate over mesoporous carbon-supported MgO catalysts Jinghui Shi a ⁎ He Wang a Yunzuo Cui a Chunling Liu a Chuanbi Li a He Sun b Mingjun Jia b ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Materials (Jilin Normal University), Ministry of Education, Changchun 130103, China Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Materials (Jilin Normal University) Ministry of Education Changchun 130103 China Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Materials (Jilin Normal University), Ministry of Education, Changchun 130103, China b Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Chemistry of Jilin Province, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, China Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Chemistry of Jilin Province College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun 130012 China Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Chemistry of Jilin Province, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Transesterification of dialkyl carbonate with various alcohols is a very attractive route for synthesizing unsymmetrical organic carbonates. Intensive efforts have been focused on developing highly active and stable heterogeneous catalysts that can efficiently catalyze the transesterification reaction at mild conditions. In this work, the synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates was conducted over a series of mesoporous carbon-supported MgO (MgO/MC) catalysts. The composition-optimized MgO/MC catalyst exhibited remarkably high activity, selectivity and stability for the transesterification of diethyl carbonates with various alcohols at the commonly used reaction temperature of 125 °C, and could even work well at ambient temperature. The uniformly dispersed MgO species should be the main active sites for the transesterification reaction, while the neighboring oxygen- and nitrogen-containing groups existed on the surface of MC support may also play positive role in synergistically activating the reagents, thus leading to efficient production of the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates at very mild conditions. Keywords MgO Mesoporous carbon Transesterification Unsymmetrical organic carbonates 1 Introduction Unsymmetrical organic carbonates, are very important chemical intermediates in pharmaceutical, lubricant and other fine chemicals, and have also been widely used as green solvents, additives to fuel [1–3]. In particular, compared with symmetrical carbonates, unsymmetrical carbonates with lower carbon numbers (e.g., ethyl methyl carbonate) have relatively high flash point and polarity, low viscosity, large dielectric constant and strong dissolving ability. These features make them to be used as ideal co-solvents for lithium battery, and play important role in improving the life and other performance of lithium battery. Unsymmetrical carbonates with higher carbon numbers (e.g., dodecyl ethyl carbonate) have good low-temperature resistance, viscosity-temperature property, lubricity, wear resistance and self-cleaning performance, and have been widely used as synthetic lubricant base oil in metal processing manufacturing, high-grade equipment, automobile and other lubrication. The traditional processes for the syntheses of unsymmetrical carbonates are generally involved in the usage of toxic reagents such as phosgene, dimethyl sulfate and pyridine [4]. With the ever-growing demand for environmental protection, recent research works have been focused on developing more simple and eco-friendly routes to synthesize various organic carbonates. Methods reported in literatures include electrochemical synthesis of organic carbonates [5,6], direct synthesis from CO2 and alcohols [7,8], and transesterification of dialkyl carbonates with other types of carbonic esters or with alcohols [9–13]. Among them, transesterification of dialkyl carbonate with various alcohols has been regarded as one of the most attractive routes to synthesize the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates due to its non-toxic raw materials and relatively simple operation conditions [14,15]. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) are two common dialkyl carbonates used for the transesterification syntheses of unsymmetrical organic carbonates with alcohols. Thus far, a variety of solid compounds or hybrid composites have been investigated as heterogeneous catalysts for these transesterification reactions, including TBD (1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene) modified mesoporous MCM-41 [16], metal organic frameworks (MOFs) derived from 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid and Zn(NO3)2 [17], organotin-oxomolybdate coordinated polymer [18], Mg-La metal oxides and CsF/Al2O3 [19–22], as well as some simple basic oxides with nanostructure, such as nanocrystalline MgO and CaO [23,24]. However, these catalysts generally require relatively high reaction temperature, i.e., at around the boiling point of DEC (126 °C), thus leading to an energy-intensive process. In addition, the chemical stability of the hybrid composite catalysts and the basic metal oxides are commonly not very ideal, especially when a higher reaction temperature was adopted. Hence, it is still a very significant subject to develop more efficient, stable heterogeneous catalysts for the green synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates under mild conditions. Recently, porous carbon materials with large surface area, developed porosity and abundant surface functional groups have shown great advantages in fabricating highly efficient carbon-supported catalysts for the application in various important catalytic processes [25–32]. For instance, Zhu et al. found that porous N-doped carbon support with more structural defects could act as a suitable stabilizer to generate supported Pd nanoparticle catalyst for selective deoxygenation of a wide variety of carbonyl compounds at room temperature and atmospheric H2 pressure [31]. By using a residue-based activated carbon derived from passion fruit seed (ACP) as a support, Lopes Barros et al. prepared a highly stable and active HPW/ACP (HPW = 12-tungstophosphoric acid) catalyst for esterification synthesis of biodiesel from oleic acid and methanol [32]. Previously, we and coauthors reported that a kind of sol–gel-synthesized porous carbon with mesoporous characteristic and abundant surface functional groups could be used as a suitable support for preparing carbon-supported metal oxides (i.e., CaO, MgO or ZnO) with excellent catalytic activity and stability for the transesterification synthesis of biodiesel from vegetable oils and the synthesis of ethyl methyl carbonate from DEC and DMC [33–36]. It was found that the abundant oxygen- and nitrogen-containing groups existed on the surface of nanoporous carbons (NC-2) or nitrogen-doped carbon materials (NCM) play critical role in achieving high dispersion of metal oxides, and in improving the chemical/structural stability of the supported metal oxide catalysts. To our knowledge, there is no report focus on the catalytic application of porous carbon supported MgO to synthesize unsymmetrical organic carbonates with DEC and alcohols. In this work, the catalytic performance of a series of mesoporous carbon supported MgO catalysts (MgO/MC) were investigated for transesterification synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates from DEC and various alcohols. It was found that very high yield of unsymmetrical organic carbonates could be achieved at very mild conditions over the condition-optimized MgO/MC catalyst. By combining a variety of characterization results, the physicochemical properties of various MgO/MC catalysts were studied, and the nature of active sites for the transesterification reaction were also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Mesoporous carbon support (MC) was synthesized by carbonization of a hybrid composite containing citric acid (CA), sucrose (SU) and aluminum phosphate (CA/SU = 1:1.6) following a procedure reported in previous work [37]. Various MgO/MC catalysts with different MgO loadings were prepared as following: a certain amount of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 5.0 mL distilled water solution, and 1.0 g of dried MC support was then added under stirring. After stirred for 4 h, the mixture was heated at 80 °C to remove water from the system, and then was thermally treated at a certain temperature (400–900 °C) for 4 h under Ar flow. The resultant catalysts were denoted as xMgO/MC-T hereafter, where x stands for the loading content of MgO by weight percent (3.0–15%), T represents the pretreated temperature. A reference catalyst of bulk MgO was synthesized from Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and NH4OH by precipitation method [38]. 2.2 Characterization N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 N analyzer. Specific surface areas were calculated using the BET model. Pore volumes were estimated at a relative pressure of 0.94 (P/P0 ), assuming full surface saturation with nitrogen. Pore size distributions were evaluated from the desorption branche of nitrogen isotherms using the BJH model. XRD were measured on an X-ray diffractometer system Rigaku PC 2500 (40 kV, 30 mA) using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. TEM and HAADF-STEM images were taken with a TEM tian G2 60–300 with probe corrector. XPS were measured on a VG ESCALAB MK II spectrometer with an Mg KR excitation. The basicity of samples was determined by the temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide technique (CO2-TPD). 100 mg of catalyst was treated at 800 °C for 2 h, and then cooled down to 50 °C in Ar. The sample was exposed to 10% CO2/Ar mixture flow for 1 h. Then the sample was flushed in Ar flow at 50 °C to remove the physically adsorbed CO2. The CO2-TPD profile of the sample was then recorded by rising the temperature from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under 20 mL/min of Ar flow. The desorbed CO2 was detected on-line by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Hiden HPR-20). The mass signal at m/z = 44 was used to determine the amount of desorbed CO2. 2.3 Catalytic performance The typical reaction procedure for unsymmetrical organic carbonates synthesis was as follows: a parallel reactor (Japan Physicochemical) was used for the catalytic test. Typically, the selected alcohol such as benzyl alcohol (2.0 mmol) and DEC (33 mmol) were transferred into a parallel reactor (100 mL) with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser, 0.5 mL of dodecane was added as internal standard. When the mixture was heated to reaction temperature (25–125 °C), 0.125 g of xMgO/MC-T was added into the reaction system to start the reaction. After completion of the reaction, the solid catalyst was filtered off and the composition of the reaction medium was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC-2010) equipped with a WondaCap WAX capillary column and FID detector. The detailed calculation process of benzyl alcohol conversion, selectivity and yield of BEC is included in the supporting information. In order to get a practical yield for BEC, an additional catalytic experiment with larger scales of reagents were also carried out under the following reaction condition: catalyst 1.25 g, benzyl alcohol 20 mmol, DEC 330 mmol, reaction temperature 25 °C, reaction time 12 h. After completion of the reaction, the solid catalyst was removed by filtration. The filtrates were treated with dried Na2SO4 and the target products were collected by distillation under reduced pressure. After that, the crude products were purified by column chromatography (silica gel: 100–200 mesh using ethyl acetate and hexane) and qualitatively analyzed by GC–MS (ISQLT) (Fig. S12-18) and NMR spectroscopy (Bruker AVANCE III HD 400 MHz) (Fig. S5-11). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm profiles of MC and various xMgO/MC-800 catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 (A) and Fig. S1. All samples display type-IV isotherms according to the IUPAC classification, characteristic of a mesoporous material. Inset shows the corresponding pore size distribution curve, revealing that the average pore size of all the xMgO/MC-800 catalysts is around 5 nm, quite consistent to the support of MC. The textural parameters of various samples are shown in Table S1. The three xMgO/MC-800 catalysts possess relatively high specific surface area (above 1000 m2/g), which are mainly inherited from the MC support. With the increase of MgO loading, the BET surface areas and the pore volumes of the catalysts decrease slightly, which should be mainly attributed to the fact that the introduced MgO species could block a small portion of the pores of the MC support. The abundant mesopores in xMgO/MC-800 catalysts should be favourable for rapid mass transfer of reagents, and may also enhance the accessibility to the catalytically active sites during catalytic reaction. The XRD patterns of MC support and xMgO/MC-800 catalysts with different MgO contents are shown in Fig. 1B. All samples exhibit two broad signals centered at 26 and 44°, that can be ascribed to (002) and (101) diffractions for glass-like carbon [39]. Moreover, no obvious crystal phase belonged to magnesium oxide could be detected for the samples of 3MgO/MC-800, 5MgO/MC-800 and 7MgO/MC-800, implying that the introduced MgO species should be highly dispersed on the surface of MC support. For 15MgO/MC-800, the characteristic peaks appeared at 36.9, 42.9, 62.3, 74.7, 78.6° are related to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) planes of cubic MgO crystal phase (JCPDS 04–0829), confirming the existence of some large grain crystalline of MgO in this catalyst. The morphology and microstructure of the representative catalysts of 5MgO/MC-800 and 15MgO/MC-800 were investigated by HTEM measurement. As shown in Fig. 2 a–c, the HTEM and HAADF images of 5MgO/MC-800 reveal the uniform dispersion of MgO species on the surface of MC support, and no obvious agglomeration of MgO particles could be detected from the whole region of the images. Additionally, the TEM and the elemental mapping images of 5MgO/MC-800 demonstrate the uniform distribution of Mg, O, and N elements throughout the carbon-based catalyst (Fig. 2d–f). The HRTEM images of 15MgO/MC-800 were also acquired for checking the distribution state of magnesium oxide on the surface of carbon materials. As shown in Fig. 2g–I, some large grain of crystalline particles (8–11 nm) could be observed, showing well-resolved lattice fringes with spacing of 0.148, 0.243 and 0.211 nm, that are corresponded to the (220), (111) and (200) interplanar distance of MgO crystal phase. This result confirms further the existence of some large grain of MgO particles in the catalyst with high MgO loading, as revealed by the XRD result. The O1s, N1s and Mg2p XPS spectra of 5MgO/MC-800 are shown in Fig. 3 . The core level O1s spectrum could be deconvoluted into three peaks of 530.8, 532.1, and 533.2 eV [40]. They are assignable to C-O or carbonyl C=O (530.4–530.8 eV), hydroxyl C-OH or ethers (531.8–532.1 eV) and lactone or anhydride groups (532.9–533.3 eV), respectively. Notably, there is no obvious O1s signal related to the lattice oxygen of MgO (529.4 ev), which might be an indication that relatively strong interaction between MgO and MC support should have been built, leading to the loss of the characteristic signal belonged to the lattice oxygen of MgO phase. The core level N1s spectrum of 5MgO/MC, shown in Fig. 3c, could be deconvoluted into two peaks of 398.3 and 400.9 eV, demonstrating the existence of pyridinic-like nitrogen (pyridine-N) and quaternary N atoms in the catalyst [41]. In addition, the high-resolution scan of Mg2p core level spectrum was depicted in Fig. 3d. Deconvolution of the Mg2p signal results in two peaks at 49.5 and 50.7 eV, which can be assigned to Mg2p 3/2 of MgO and RCOO-Mg, respectively [42,43]. The existence of carboxylate species like RCOO-Mg in 5MgO/MC-800 catalyst may further confirm the presence of relatively strong interaction between MgO species and the oxygen-containing groups on the surface of the mesoporous carbon material. Such kind of interfacial RCOO-Mg species may act as anchoring sites to achieve high dispersion of the rest MgO species on the surface of MC support, thus leading to the formation of a large number of uniformly distributed MgO species on MC support [44–46]. CO2-TPD experiments were carried out to characterize the basic sites of the MC supported MgO catalysts. It should be mentioned here that the main TPD signals are derived from the desorption of CO2, since no obvious MS signals assigned to the desorption of water or other molecules (e.g., CO, NOx) could be detected in the temperature range of 50–600 °C (see Fig. S2). In addition, no any clear TCD-MS signals could be detected in the temperature range when a blank TPD experiment for 5MgO/MC-800 (without pre-adsorption of CO2) was carried out, thus excluding the effect of the decomposition of surface groups on the MC support. As shown in Fig. 4 , obvious desorption peak of CO2 centered at 140 °C and 425 °C could detected for various xMgO/MC-800 catalysts, indicating the presence of a certain amount of weak basic sites and medium strong basic sites. With the increase of MgO contents from 3 to 5%, both the peak area and the peak intensity of the CO2-TPD signals increase gradually, indicating the formation of more basic sites over the catalysts with higher loading of MgO. After further increasing the MgO content to 15%, the desportion peak shifts somewhat towards the higher temperature, demonstrating the presence of stronger basic sites on the surface of 15MgO/MC-800. Combined with the characterization results of XRD, it can be deduced that these stronger basic sites should be related to the formation of some large-size MgO particles on the surface of 15MgO/MC-800 catalyst. To check the effect of pretreating temperature on the dispersity of MgO over the MC supported catalysts, some addition experiments were carried out. By thermally treating the the catalyst precursor of 5MgO/MC at different temperatures, a series samples named 5MgO/MC-T (T = 400, 600, 800 and 900 °C) were obtained. As shown in Fig. S3, there are no detectable diffraction signals belonged to MgO crystalline in the XRD patterns of various 5MgO/MC-T catalysts, suggesting that no serious agglomeration of the supported magnesium oxides occurs during the thermal-treatment process, even at relatively high temperaure (i.e., 900 °C). XPS results show that the surface elemental compositions of these catalysts change somewhat with the increase of pretreating temperatures (in Table S2). The surface content of Mg increases gradually from 3.3% to 5.5% when the pretreating temperature increases from 400 to 800 °C, such change might be caused by the fact that the relative content of oxygen decreases obviously with temperature. These results provide further evidence that the strong interaction between MgO species and the surface oxygen-containing groups has been built during the high-temperature treatment. With further increasing the temperature to 900 °C, the Mg content decreases somewhat (to 3.2%). This should be assigned to the weight loss of a part of Mg in the form of Mg vapor, caused by the high-temperaure reduction of a portion of MgO with carbon. Similar phenomenon has already been reported in early literatures [47,48]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic properties of various xMgO/MC-T catalysts were first investigated for the synthesis of benzyl ethyl carbonate (BEC) from DEC and benzyl alcohol, which is a typical model reaction for the transesterification synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates. As shown in Table S3, a blank test revealed that the transesterification reaction would not occur at 125 °C in the absence of the catalyst. In additions, a very low conversion of benzyl alcohol (7.1%) could be obtained in presence of MC-800 support after 60 min reaction at 125 °C. The reference catalyst of the bulk MgO exhibits a moderate catalytic activity with a 56% conversion of benzyl alcohol after 30 min reaction, suggesting that such basic metal oxide is effective for the transesterification reaction. Fig. 5 A shows that all the 5MgO/MC-T catalysts thermally treated at different temperature are catalytically active for the transesterification reaction at the reaction temperature of 125 °C. They all present very high selectivity (nearly 100%) to the unsymmetrical product of BEC when a high ratio of DEC to alcohols (i.e., 16.5/1) is adopted for the catalytic test. Apparently, relatively high pretreated temperature, i.e., 800 °C, is more suitable for getting a higher conversion of benzyl alcohol in a shorter reaction time. This result is well consistent to the previous reported results on the study of porous carbon support CaO and ZnO catalysts, showing that 800 °C is an optimized pretreated temperature for generating highly active carbon-based metal oxides catalysts [34,36,49]. Fig. 5B shows the catalytic properties of xMgO/MC-800 catalysts with MgO loadings ranging from 3.0 to 15 wt%. Among them, 3MgO/MC-800 presents a relatively low activity, with a 42% conversion of benzyl alcohol after 1 h reaction. The highest catalytic activity is achieved over 5MgO/MC-800 (with 5 wt% loading of MgO), giving a 95% conversion of benzyl alcohol after 3 min reaction. Notably, the TOF of 5MgO/MC-800 can reach 243 h−1, much higher than that of literature reported catalysts operated at similar reaction conditions [18,19,23,24]. With further increasing MgO content, the catalytic activities of 7MgO/MC-800 and 15MgO/MC-800 decrease gradually, which might be mainly attributed to the formation of some large grain of MgO particles in these catalysts. In addition, the effect of catalyst loading inside the reactor on the catalytic activity of 5MgO/MC-800 was also investigated at the reaction temperature of 125 °C (Fig. S4). It was found that relatively high transesterification activity could also be achieved after decreasing the loading of 5MgO/MC-800 catlayst to 1/5 (or 1/10) of its original loading amount, showing a 92% (or 78%) conversion of benzyl alcohol after 30 min reaction, confirming further the excellent catalytic property of 5MgO/MC-800 catalyst. In view of the high catalytic efficiency of 5MgO/MC catalyst at high temperature, we further investigated the effect of reaction temperatures on the transesterification activities over 5MgO/MC-800 catalyst (in Table 1 ). It was found that decreasing the reaction temperature could lead to the gradually decrease of catalytic activity. Interestingly, benzyl alcohol can still be efficiently converted to BEC at a temperature as low as 25 °C, a 98% yield of BEC could be obtained after 12 h. It should be mentioned here that the bulk MgO does not show obvious activity at such low reaction temperature after 2 h reaction (Table S3). To our knowledge, this is the first report that the transesterification of benzyl alcohol and DEC could be effectively achieved at room temperature (in Fig. 6 C). Additional recycling experiments show that 5MgO/MC-800 catalyst has good recoverability, which could be easily recycled without obvious loss in catalytic activity after thermally treating the spent catalyst at 800 °C (in Fig. 6A). A heterogeneous leaching test, the so called Sheldon’s test [50], demonstrates that 5MgO/MC-800 is a truly heterogeneous catalyst for the transesterification reaction (Fig. 6B), since no detectable leaching of the active species could be observed during the course of reaction. In addition, by enlarging the reaction scale to 10 times (i.e., catalyst 1.25 g, benzyl alcohol 20 mmol, DEC 330 mmol, reaction temperature 25 °C, 12 h), an relatively high isolated BEC yield of 96% could be obtained after completing the reaction, which is quite near from the datum of 98% obtained from GC analysis. Besides, the excessive DEC separated by distillation could be directly reused in the subsequent reaction without further purification, thus guarantee a high efficiency for recycling the DEC. Moreover, the effect of the molar ratio of alcohol to DEC on the catalytic property of 5MgO/MC-800 was also studied at the reaction temperature of 25 °C. As shown in Fig. 7 and Table S4, with the increase of alcohol ratio, the conversion of benzyl alcohol decreases somewhat due mainly to the shift of reaction equilibrium toward the reactant direction. Meanwhile, the selectivity of BEC decreases gradually from 99% to 92 when the ratio of alcohol/DEC varies from 1/16.5 to 1/5, accompanied with the appearance of the only side product of dibenzyl carbonate. This result confirms further that keeping large excess of DEC is an important precondition to effectively inhibit the generation of the symmetrical carbonate, and to guarantee the fairly high selectivity to the unsymmetrical product of BEC under the test condition. The catalytic activities of 5MgO/MC-800 for the transesterification of DEC with various alcohols were also investigated to check the application range of the catalyst. As shown in Table S5, it could efficiently convert various alcohols to the corresponding unsymmetrical carbonates with high selectivity (99%) when the reactions were carried out at 125 °C. These transesterification reactions may also proceed substantially at the ambient temperature of 25 °C, in an activity order of aliphatic alcohols > aromatic alcohols > alicyclic alcohols (Table 2 ). Apparently, both the steric hindrance and electronic effect may influence the accessibly and the acidity of the alcohols, thus resulting in different reactivity for transesterification reaction. According to the related literatures, it was known that the transesterification alcohols with dialkyl carbonates may proceed through a nucleophilic reaction mechanism over the basic catalyst [18,23,24]. Therefore, the basic sites like the highly dispersed MgO species in 5MgO/MC-800 should be the catalytically active centers for the transesterification reaction. However, it seems quite hard to say that the superior low-temperature activity of the catalyst is just derived from this kind of MgO species, concerning the fact that other kind of supported MgO catalysts as well as the bulk MgO have never shown such high catalytic activity for the transesterification alcohols with dialkyl carbonates. In a work reported by Zhu and coworkers, they proposed that carboxylate species bonded on the surface of K2CO3/ZrO2 catalyst were the active sites for the DMC transesterification with tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol [51]. In the present case, it seems reasonable to infer that the specific interface species such as RCOO-Mg might be the main active sites for transesterification, while other surface oxygen- or nitrogen-containing groups (like carbonyl group or pyridine N) may also play positive role in participating the activation of reagents. It was known that the hydroxyl groups in alcohols and the carbonyl group in DEC might be easily activated by Lewis acid-base pairs of Mg2+–O2- (derived from the interface species of magnesium carboxylates), to generate the catalytically active intermediates [23,24]. In this case, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed on the basis of the related literatures and the main features of the active sites in MgO/MC catalysts (in Scheme 1 ). The catalytic cycle may start from the activation of alcohol on Mg2+–O2- sites linked with the surface caroxyl group, meanwhile, DEC was activated by the neighbouring MgO sites anchored on the surface of the catalyst (step a). Then, the generated RO- attacks the activated carbonyl group of DEC (step b). Finally, the H+ dissociated from ROH interacts directly with the ethoyl group of DEC to release EtOH and the corresponding unsymmetrical carbonate (step c). 4 Conclusions Mesoporous carbon supported MgO/MC catalysts prepared by impregnation method showed very high catalytic activity for the transesterification synthesis of unsymmetrical carbonates at ambient temperature. The abundant oxygen-containing groups on the surface of mesoporous carbon play critical role in generating interfacial RCOO-Mg like species, and resulting in the uniform distribution of the rest of MgO species on the surface of MC support. The highly dispersed MgO species linked with the surface oxygen-containing groups of MC support should be the main catalytically active sites for the transesterification of diethyl carbonates with alcohols. The relative strong interaction between MgO and MC support is beneficial for fabricating structure stable and catalytically active interfacial species that can efficiently produce the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates at very mild conditions. This work may provide some useful information on revealing the nature of the catalytically active sites and on designing more efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the transesterification synthesis of unsymmetrical carbonates at mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: Transesterification of dialkyl carbonate with various alcohols is a very attractive route for synthesizing unsymmetrical organic carbonates. Intensive efforts have been focused on developing highly active and stable heterogeneous catalysts that can efficiently catalyze the transesterification reaction at mild conditions. In this work, the synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates was conducted over a series of mesoporous carbon-supported MgO (MgO/MC) catalysts. The composition-optimized MgO/MC catalyst exhibited remarkably high activity, selectivity and stability for the transesterification of diethyl carbonates with various alcohols at the commonly used reaction temperature of 125 °C, and could even work well at ambient temperature. The uniformly dispersed MgO species should be the main active sites for the transesterification reaction, while the neighboring oxygen- and nitrogen-containing groups existed on the surface of MC support may also play positive role in synergistically activating the reagents, thus leading to efficient production of the corresponding unsymmetrical organic carbonates at very mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient synthesis of unsymmetrical organic carbonates from alcohols and diethyl carbonate over mesoporous carbon-supported MgO catalysts
